Title: Extended Ancestry of the Dinosauria
Keywords:
Reptilia, Archosauromorpha, Archosauriformes, Archosauria,
Diapsida, Dinosauria, Phylogenetic analysis
Abstract:
The origin of the iconic clade Dinosauria remains in a
state of flux. Some workers recover pterosaurs close to dinosaurs.
Others recover silesaurids. Still others recover lagerpetids, or all
three. False assumptions and taxon exclusion have been long-standing
problems. No workers have experimented with a wider gamut of included
taxa. No workers have checked their results to make sure a gradual
accumulation of traits could be traced for all derived taxa. Here a wide
gamut (1138 taxa) phylogenetic analysis of the Reptilia and their
ancestors provides a set of genus- to specimen-based out-group taxa for
all included derived taxa, including the Dinosauria. Every current
candidate is tested here (and more than a thousand others). When given
this unprecedented opportunity pterosaurs nest with lepidosaurs,
silesaurids nest with poposaurs and Lagerpeton nests with Tropidosuchus,
far from dinosaurs. Here the clade Crocodylomorpha nests with the
Dinosauria, along with a long list of ancestral taxa extending back to
the Late Devonian. As a series these document a gradual accumulation of
derived traits, from the origin of the cleidoic egg and the first
appearance of the diapsid skull to bipedal locomotion and a suite of
features found only in basal dinosaurs.
